>From: "Chris Eppstein" <ceppstein@...>
>
>So your argument is that we really don't need anything other than 
>assertTrue? I'd have to disagree.

That might be a simplification of my position.

>JUnit is a TESTING FRAMEWORK. By using it, testing should be made easier. 
>I'd like to not have to reinvent the wheel for many of these assertions. I 
>understand that I can easily write my own assertion library in just a 
>couple hours but why should I have to?

Well, you don't. Just write methods that answer boolean and use assertTrue() 
or assertFalse(). The only difference is that you're writing:

public static boolean somethingIsTrue() {
    return someBooleanCondition;
}

and using it this way:

assertTrue( "Hey man, it ain't good.", somethingIsTrue() );

as opposed to writing

public static void assertSomethingIsTrue( final String failureMessage ) {
    assertTrue( failureMessage, somethingIsTrue() );
}

and using it this way:

assertSomethingIsTrue( "Hey man, it ain't good." );

Of course, you may want a version with and without the failure message, so 
as not to make it mandatory.... aww, hell, you're just rewriting 
assertTrue(), anyway.

>Certainly, after years of use, we have identified many assertions that 
>would be useful to the community at large. As they are identified, it seems 
>natural for JUnit to provide them in future releases.

Maybe this is just an issue of terminology. There are no new assertions, 
merely new boolean conditions to assert. The assertion mechanism itself is 
not what's new. Hell, even assertEquals() is just a shorthand for

assertTrue( equals( a, b ) );

public static boolean equals(final Object a, final Object b) {
    return (a == b) || (a != null && a.equals(b));
}

(Of course, assertTrue( a.equals(b) ) is no good, since a could be null and 
this would blow up.)

So if you find yourself writing assertX() methods that do nothing more than 
turn around and use some method that answers a boolean, it is cleaner simply 
to use assertTrue() and assertFalse() around your boolean method.

I would be interested in seeing an assertX() method whose boolean condition 
couldn't be easily refactored out without overly affecting the unit test. 
This refactoring would reduce coupling and increase cohesion. Good Things, 
no?
